question.content:
**Graph a line that contains the point $(-6,1)$ and has a slope of $5$.**

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
###Graphing the first point

To graph a line, we need to find two points that are on it. Then we can drag the movable points to those points.

We already have one point, $(-6,1)$, and we can use the slope of the line to find another point.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The point negative six, one is plotted and labeled.

hints.content:
###Use the slope to graph another point

We want the slope to be $5$. Let's look at this slope as a fraction to help us graph the line:

$\text{slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\maroonD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\maroonD{\Delta x}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{5}}{\maroonD{1}}$

Starting at $(-6,1)$, let's go $\purpleD{5\text{ units up}}$ and $\maroonD{1\text{ unit to the right}}$ to plot another point on the line:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points negative six, one and negative five, six are plotted and labeled. There is a vertical dotted segment from negative six, one to negative six, six that is labeled five. There is a horizontal dotted segment from negative six, six to negative five, six that is labeled one.

hints.content:
###The answer

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:

hints.content:
###Use the slope to graph another point

We want the slope to be $4$. Let's look at this slope as a fraction to help us graph the line:

$\text{slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\maroonD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\maroonD{\Delta x}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{4}}{\maroonD{1}}$

Starting at $(3,0)$, let's go $\purpleD{4\text{ units up}}$ and $\maroonD{1\text{ unit to the right}}$ to plot another point on the line:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points three, zero and four, four are plotted and labeled. There is a vertical dotted segment from three, zero to three, four that is labeled four. There is a horizontal dotted segment from three, four to four, four that is labeled one.

hints.content:
###The answer

Starting at $(-5,-3)$, let's go $\purpleD{2\text{ units down}}$ and $\maroonD{1\text{ unit to the right}}$ to plot another point on the line:

question.content:
**Graph a line that contains the point $(6,-5)$ and has a slope of $-\dfrac{2}{3}$.**

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
###Graphing the first point

To graph a line, we need to find two points that are on it. Then we can drag the movable points to those points.

We already have one point, $(6,-5)$, and we can use the slope of the line to find another point.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The point six, negative five is plotted and labeled.

hints.content:
###Use the slope to graph another point

We want the slope to be $-\dfrac23$:

$\text{slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\maroonD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\maroonD{\Delta x}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{-2}}{\maroonD{3}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{2}}{\maroonD{-3}}$

Starting at $(6,-5)$, we don't have room on the given grid to go $2$ units down and $3$ units right. So let's go $\purpleD{2\text{ units up}}$ and $\maroonD{3\text{ units to the left}}$ to plot another point on the line:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points six, negative five and three, negative three are plotted and labeled. There is a vertical dotted segment from six, negative five to six, negative three that is labeled two. There is a horizontal dotted segment from six, negative three to three, negative three that is labeled negative three.

hints.content:
###The answer

[[☃ grapher 2]]

question.content:
**Graph a line that contains the point $(-2,7)$ and has a slope of $4$.**

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
###Graphing the first point

To graph a line, we need to find two points that are on it. Then we can drag the movable points to those points.

We already have one point, $(-2,7)$, and we can use the slope of the line to find another point.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The point negative two, seven is plotted and labeled.

hints.content:
###Use the slope to graph another point

We want the slope to be $4$:

$\text{slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\maroonD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\maroonD{\Delta x}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{4}}{\maroonD{1}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{-4}}{\maroonD{-1}}$

Starting at $(-2,7)$, we don't have room on the given grid to go $4$ units up and $1$ unit right. So let's go $\purpleD{4\text{ units down}}$ and $\maroonD{1\text{ unit to the left}}$ to plot another point on the line:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points negative two, seven and negative three, three are plotted and labeled. There is a vertical dotted segment from negative two, seven to negative two, three that is labeled negative four. There is a horizontal dotted segment from negative two, three to negative three, three that is labeled negative one.

hints.content:
###The answer

[[☃ grapher 3]]

question.content:
**Graph a line with a slope of $\dfrac14$ that contains the point $(6,3)$.**

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
###Graphing the first point

To graph a line, we need to find two points that are on it. Then we can drag the movable points to those points.

hints.content:
###Use the slope to graph another point

We want the slope to be $\dfrac14$:

$\text{slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\maroonD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\maroonD{\Delta x}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{1}}{\maroonD{4}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{-1}}{\maroonD{-4}}$

Starting at $(6,3)$, we don't have room on the given grid to go $1$ unit up and $4$ units right. So let's go $\purpleD{1\text{ unit down}}$ and $\maroonD{4\text{ units to the left}}$ to plot another point on the line:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points six, three and two, two are plotted and labeled. There is a vertical dotted segment from six, three to six two that is labeled one. There is a horizontal dotted segment from six, two to two, two that is labeled negative four.

hints.content:
###The answer

Starting at $(-3,-4)$, we don't have room on the given grid to go $5$ units down and $1$ unit right. So let's go $\purpleD{5\text{ units up}}$ and $\maroonD{1\text{ unit to the left}}$ to plot another point on the line:
